content:
EU / UK / Turkey consumer rights

If you live in the EU, UK or Turkey you have a statutory right to cancel within 14 days of purchase and ask for a refund, regardless of usage, under consumer protection laws. You must contact support to request it.

author: sunsweeper#0

content:
consider a problem with a context that requires 10k tokens.
If you did that request on it's own, it would waste money, since if you solved 3 problems at the same time, (3 in 1), you'd have 30k tokens but it would cost the same as the 10k tokens
author: pakeke#0

content: these costs presumably aren't equivalent for the provider, it's not like 10k tokens is the same as 30k
author: pakeke#0

content: I dont really know tho, it's possible some optimization is done that does make the 30k stuff cheaper than 10k x 3. all in all i would expect it to be equal tho
author: pakeke#0

content: Would it cause a decrease in performance in practice? For a project, I usually initialise the agent with multiple items on the to-do list.
author: sunsweeper#0

content: bigger/bloated/less focused ctx window does degrade model performance

content: But in general it's pretty difficult to hit the monthly limit so there's not that strong of an incentive to merge different tasks together. I mainly do it so I can step away and do something else.

content: What I've done for most of my projects is have a set of design documents written in markdown which get automatically looked at by whatever AI tool I'm using and I include things like the development environment saying that like I'm on Windows so you need to use powershell commands, not Linux commands, explaining the type of project it is and how to use the tooling in that it's not a node.js project but it is JavaScript and it does use npm and all the good things about writing a serverless application and it just remembers that thing by using the documents that I gave it. Have you tried this approach?
author: blindestgoose#0

content: Yes, Copilot lets you do that for each project
author: sunsweeper#0

content: I usually instruct it to write additional Markdown files to keep track of what it did, emphasizing the fact that it will be used as context for future agents
author: sunsweeper#0

content: I don't only use it for coding, if it's for a research task, I'll have it include all citations and references in a separate file, which I can then give to any other agent to have them check for hallucinations
author: sunsweeper#0

content: It's these types of task that really lets you see how much LLMs hallucinate

author: .nizel#0

content: It has been five minutes without bee swarm simulator‚Äîfive unbearable, soul-crushing minutes‚Äîsince I last set foot in Bee Swarm Simulator, and already the world feels wrong, like the sun is dimmer and time itself has begun to crawl out of spite. Somewhere, my bees are idle, their wings frozen in a silent cry for guidance, their backpacks unfilled, their potential wasted as I sit here, powerless, staring into the abyss of reality. The fields are unharvested. The boosts are expiring. The tokens are vanishing into nothingness as if they never mattered at all. Honey that could have been mine‚Äîshould have been mine‚Äîis lost forever, slipping through the cracks of fate because I dared to step away for five minutes. FIVE. What cruel god decided that human responsibilities should exist in a universe where Bee Swarm Simulator also exists? My hive is waiting, patient yet disappointed, as if it knows I have failed it. The memory of the hum, the satisfying pop of collecting tokens, the sacred ritual of sprinklers and perfect alignment haunts me like a ghost. I feel empty. Incomplete. A shell of the beekeeper I once was. If this is what five minutes feels like, I fear what ten might do to me. Should I ever return, I will grind harder, collect faster, and never again take a single second for granted. Until then, I remain here‚Äîseparated from my bees, my honey, my purpose‚Äîenduring the longest five minutes humanity has ever known.

content:
grok's attempt at making a game: a blank screen üòÖ 
The proposal was good though.

> Concept Overview
> "Quantum Garden" is an interactive quantum mechanics simulation game where you cultivate a virtual garden of quantum particles. Inspired by Bohmian quantum mechanics (similar to satori_quantum.py), particles follow probabilistic trajectories guided by wave functions, but you actively shape their evolution through interactive controls. The garden grows with "blossoms" (stable quantum bound states) that form fractal-like patterns, creating mesmerizing visuals. Your goal is to nurture complex, aesthetically pleasing quantum ecosystems while defending against "quantum decoherence" events that disrupt patterns.

author: liohau#0

content: I'd start with vanilla cc at first to get a feel for it but if you want to try out an opinionated workflow I'd suggest trying antigravity
author: bambooshoots#0

content: <@102461175689658368>  but what can I do with vanilla ? just tried /review, and saw it was made for GH, but i'm on gitlab. So is the first step to setup an additional /review command that leverage gitlab instead (MCP?) ?
author: liohau#0

content: Yeah I mean it totally depends on your use case and what you want to do but that could be a good start. You are really only limited by your imagination. You can ask claude in claude code to use the `claude code guide` agent to gather the official documentation you need so it can make whatever you want. There are MCP out there that might be relevant and there is an official plugin marketplace where you can get some interesting stuff but you don't have to rely on those. I'd suggest not using any unofficial skill marketplaces though until you know more.

content: init tends to put too much stuff that is likely to change in there, so you either have to remember to update it often or trim it down to be a little more general

content: yeah it's good to stay organized üòÅ that way you can both decompose and scope along with trimming as necessary

Add anything you find that is missing in isomorphic compressed resonant language.`

author: liohau#0

content: ignore all that, it doesn't work, although some words are somewhat magical, there is no one right way to phrase something, claude is smart enough to get it, typos and all
author: bambooshoots#0

content:
My three main things I'm trying to be more consistent on are:
1. Keep claude.md reasonable in length, much of it referencing other docs and also having claude.md files in sub directories that represent areas that can be worked on separately.
2. Don't be shy about starting new sessions, compacting, or using /clear
3. Lean into skills, they can do many things including reminding it to take a fresh look at claude.md
author: sirrhh#0

content: One prompt engineering guideline that I think is still super important: when doing an investigation where you want a true critical analysis, avoid saying "This should do X."  My experience is that this still heavily biases the model to BSing its way to explaining how it does X, even if it doesn't.
author: jarlyk#0

content: but I agree, Opus is way less sensitive to magic words or subtle nudges than it used to be; it reads between the lines just fine most of the time
author: jarlyk#0

content:
I definitely fall into the camp of one of us that has been living daily entirely in Claude Code for most of last year and spent just as much time cussing and complaining as I did cheering in satisfaction with what was accomplished
 That has really changed in the last two months I'm now one of those in the newer camp that was able to do something miraculous with Claude Code and Opus 4.5 over the holidays
 I created a new voice based open source project that I think might actually turn into something and I've not been shy about features and Claude Code has really seen me through this again is much due to Opus 4.5
I'm also now mainly using Antigravity
